children.subject: 375 is for current TAs 370 is for aspiring ones

Actually Kartik, CS370 is open to first-time UGSIs as well, and we're hoping to have some take CS370 with us in the fall. We will have some modified assignments and adjustments to the tutoring requirement so it's as useful as it is for non-TAs, but we think first-time TAs will find the course worthwhile.

To your question, CS375 is almost exclusively taken concurrently with being a first-time TA while CS370 can be taken as early as once you've completed CS61A and have (hopefully) academic interned or tutored--via course staff or CS Mentors.

CS375 is a mixture of graduate students and undergraduate students who are teaching for the first time, and CS370 consists solely of undergraduates who are either AI's, tutors, first-time TAs, or even readers interested in teaching.

In terms of curriculum, both courses have overlap, but CS370 is 3 units instead of 2, and requires a teaching or tutoring component for up to 3 hours a week (1-2 hours if you're a TA). Also, CS370 is designed to be a smaller learning experience so we do not allow any one class to be larger than 30 students. There are students who enjoy(ed) both classes so I'd encourage you to ask around and choose the one that's the best fit for your needs.

Thanks!
What is the difference between 370 and 375? If I want to be a TA, tutor in the future, which one should I take?
Academic Intern are volunteer positions and do not have a pedagogy-course requirement

As Nicole mentioned, you definitely do that. That being said, we will be offering a summer 370 *only* for summer AI's and tutors who would like to take the class to improve their teaching ability before fall begins. These students wouldn't have to take CS375 if they become TAs in the future, but regardless, it is not required to AI or tutor in summer or any other session. Good question!
If I want to be a summer academic intern for CS61A, do I need to take this class as well?
As it's P/NP only, it does not count.
Out of curiosity, does CS 370 count for the 45 Engineering Units needed for EECS? I'm planning on taking it either way next semester, but I want to know if it'd count for that.

I don't think it helped me secure a TA position; it's much more important to be a reader for the course and get an A. I'm a rising junior; I academic interned for CS70 but definitely should have been a reader; I then read for CS189 and am now TAing CS70. I don't think at any point CS370 really came up; I doubt the Professors who are doing hiring would really know what it is, as so far through multiple interviews I've had to explain what CS370 is. Teaching ability is overall not valued very highly in undergraduate TAs unfortunately, so much as high GPA/experience is, because there are so many applicants. 

That being said, the course was awesome and helped me learn a lot about teaching pedagogy.

Will taking CS 370 help me in becoming a more attractive candidate for being a TA? When I apply for a position and they see I’ve taken this class will they prefer me and/or see I have the teaching ability to succeed? (Provided I have an A/A- in the course and at least a semester of academic interning) I really want to be a TA for a course but I am already a rising junior and feel time is limited.
Does it fulfill any L&S breath requirements?

history.content:
Hello, all you wonderful computer scientists!

CS 370 is a class you can take concurrently with academic interning / tutoring / TA-ing, where you can get hands-on teaching experience while learning how to be an effective communicator and mentor to the next generation of computer science students. If you're interested in becoming a stand-out tutor or eventually a TA, then this is a great way to get the experience we look for while hiring new staff. It also satisfies the pedagogy course requirement for TAs, so if you're interested in continuing with course staff then this is a class that you want to take!

The application will be used for both the summer and fall terms. Last semester we expected far fewer applicants than we received; to compensate we have doubled the class size but applications may remain somewhat competitive. That said, we don't require any prior teaching experience to take the class (we care more about your interest in teaching) so apply if you're interested! The application is available here: bit.ly/2vDsw3q. You will need to use your UC Berkeley email address to access it.

Applications will be processed on a rolling basis in 2-week cycles. That means every two weeks we will review our new applicants. Then you will either be added to the class, or put on the waiting list. You will be notified of updates via email. The first cycle will be on Sunday, May 13. If you submit your application before then, you will be included in the first cycle. (PS: If you apply earlier rather than later, you are more likely to receive notice of acceptance or a higher position on the waiting list.)

Also, if you plan to take CS 370 over the summer note that it will officially count towards your fall units (not your summer units) and it will not contribute towards summer tuition or financial aid.

Looking forward to the Summer and Fall!
history.subject: [Future TAs+Tutors] CS 370 is Open!
